Problem:
Consider a linear operator \\( L \\) acting on a function \\( u(x) \\) defined by an integral transform \\( L[u(x)] = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} k(x, s) u(s) ds \\), where \\( k(x, s) \\) is the kernel of the transformation. Suppose we introduce a perturbation function \\( p(x) \\) which modifies \\( u(x) \\) to \\( v(x) = u(x) + p(x) \\).

If an additional modification \\( q(x) \\) is applied after time \\( t_1 \\), modifying \\( u(x) \\) to \\( w(x) = v(x) + q(x) \\), will the transformed outcome \\( L[w(x)] \\) still reflect the actions of both \\( p(x) \\) and \\( q(x) \\), or just depend on \\( L[u(x)] \\)?
Explanation: The linearity of \\( L \\) implies that \\( L[w(x)] = L[u(x)] + L[p(x)] + L[q(x)] \\). Thus, both the actions of \\( p(x) \\) and \\( q(x) \\) are reflected in the final transformation, adding to the output from \\( L[u(x)] \\).
